title: Steve Wright (American football, born 1959)
text:
Stephen Hough Wright (born April 8, 1959) is a former <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="offensive%20tackle">offensive tackle</a> in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> for the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a>, <a href="Indianapolis%20Colts">Indianapolis Colts</a> and <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Raiders">Los Angeles Raiders</a>. He was also a member of the <a href="Oakland%20Invaders">Oakland Invaders</a> of the <a href="United%20States%20Football%20League">United States Football League</a>. He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at <a href="University%20of%20Northern%20Iowa">Northern Iowa</a> and then played ten <a href="Professional%20sports">professional</a> seasons for four teams from <a href="1981%20NFL%20season">1981</a>–<a href="1992%20NFL%20season">1992</a>. He also appeared on "" where he placed tenth and became the third jury member.
Early years.
Wright attended <a href="Wayzata%20High%20School">Wayzata High School</a>, where he practiced football, <a href="basketball">basketball</a>, <a href="track%20and%20field">track</a>, and <a href="ice%20hockey">hockey</a>. He was an <a href="All-American">All-American</a> in the <a href="shot%20put">shot put</a> and <a href="discus%20throw">discus throw</a>.
He accepted a football scholarship from the <a href="University%20of%20Northern%20Iowa">University of Northern Iowa</a>. He played <a href="offensive%20tackle">offensive tackle</a> during his first three years. As a senior he was switched to <a href="tight%20end">tight end</a>, registering 8 receptions for 73 yards and one <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>.
In 1997, he was inducted into the <a href="University%20of%20Northern%20Iowa">Northern Iowa</a> Athletics Hall of Fame.
Professional career.
Dallas Cowboys.
Wright was signed as an <a href="undrafted%20free%20agent">undrafted free agent</a> by the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> after the <a href="1981%20NFL%20Draft">1981 NFL Draft</a>. He appeared in 16 games, playing mainly on <a href="special%20teams">special teams</a> and as a backup <a href="offensive%20tackle">offensive tackle</a>.
In <a href="1982%20NFL%20season">1982</a>, he was moved to the backup <a href="Guard%20%28gridiron%20football%29">guard</a> position. Because of an injury to <a href="Kurt%20Petersen%20%28American%20football%29">Kurt Petersen</a>, he was the <a href="Guard%20%28American%20and%20Canadian%20football%29">right guard</a> in the <a href="offensive%20line">offensive line</a> that blocked on <a href="Tony%20Dorsett%23Legacy">Tony Dorsett's record 99-yard touchdown run</a> against the <a href="Minnesota%20Vikings">Minnesota Vikings</a>. Also while with the Cowboys, Wright additionally blocked for another future "Survivor" contestant, <a href="Gary%20Hogeboom">Gary Hogeboom</a> (""), who was the team's backup <a href="quarterback">quarterback</a>.
Baltimore/Indianapolis Colts (first stint).
On August 26, <a href="1983%20NFL%20season">1983</a>, he was traded to the <a href="Baltimore%20Colts%20%281953%E2%80%931983%29">Baltimore Colts</a> in exchange for a sixth round draft choice (#144-<a href="Kurt%20Ploeger">Kurt Ploeger</a>). In his first year with the Baltimore Colts he started ten games at <a href="right%20guard">right guard</a>. He missed 3 games with an ankle injury. In <a href="1984%20NFL%20season">1984</a>, when the team moved to Indianapolis, he replaced an injured <a href="Chris%20Hinton">Chris Hinton</a> at <a href="left%20tackle">left tackle</a> and started nine games.
Oakland Invaders (USFL).
In December <a href="1984%20USFL%20season">1984</a>, he signed with the <a href="Michigan%20Panthers">Michigan Panthers</a> of the <a href="United%20States%20Football%20League">United States Football League</a>. Before the start of the next season, the Panthers decided to merge with the <a href="Oakland%20Invaders">Oakland Invaders</a>. The team would reach the USFL Championship Game, losing to the <a href="Baltimore%20Stars">Baltimore Stars</a>. Wright, who wore #70 with the Invaders, scored a <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a> in a May game against the <a href="Denver%20Gold">Denver Gold</a> when Invaders quarterback <a href="Bobby%20Hebert">Bobby Hebert</a> completed a two-yard pass to Wright, who was tackle eligible on the play.
Indianapolis Colts (second stint).
On July 16, <a href="1986%20NFL%20season">1986</a>, Wright returned to the <a href="NFL">NFL</a>, signing with the <a href="Indianapolis%20Colts">Indianapolis Colts</a> as a <a href="free%20agent">free agent</a>. He was a surprise cut on August 18.
Los Angeles Raiders.
In <a href="1987%20NFL%20season">1987</a>, he signed with the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Raiders">Los Angeles Raiders</a> and was released on September 7. After the players went on a strike on the third week of the season, those games were canceled (reducing the 16 game season to 15) and the <a href="NFL">NFL</a> decided that the games would be played with <a href="strikebreaker">replacement players</a>. Wright was re-signed to be a part of the Raiders replacement team, that was given the mock name "Masqueraiders" by the media. He ended up playing well in those games as the starter at <a href="right%20tackle">right tackle</a> and was kept for the rest of the season playing mainly as a backup.
He was waived on September first, <a href="1988%20NFL%20season">1988</a>, before being re-signed during the second week of the regular season. In <a href="1990%20NFL%20season">1990</a>, he became a full-time starter at <a href="right%20tackle">right tackle</a> after replacing an injured <a href="Bruce%20Wilkerson">Bruce Wilkerson</a> and keeping his job after Wilkerson returned and was moved to <a href="left%20tackle">left tackle</a>.
In <a href="1992%20NFL%20season">1992</a>, he missed nine games with a right shoulder injury. On August, 23, <a href="1993%20NFL%20season">1993</a>, he was placed on the <a href="injured%20reserve%20list">injured reserve list</a>. He retired from professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> in June <a href="1994%20NFL%20season">1994</a> at the age of 35.
Personal life.
Wright founded Cloudburst, a company that provides sideline misting systems. He sold the business in 2000. Today, Wright lives in <a href="Huntington%20Beach%2C%20California">Huntington Beach, California</a>.
In 2011, Wright appeared as a contestant on of the American competitive <a href="reality%20television">reality television</a> series "<a href="Survivor%20%28U.S.%20TV%20series%29">Survivor</a>". On Day 30, he was the 13th person voted out of the main game and was sent to <a href="Survivor%20%28TV%20series%29%23Redemption%20Island">Redemption Island</a>. He was eliminated on Day 31. He's best remembered for his disagreements with <a href="Phillip%20Sheppard">Phillip Sheppard</a> throughout the season, where Phillip claimed their rivalry was racially motivated.
